description: Number of ternary cubefree words of length n.
links: A. M. Shur, Growth properties of power-free languages, Computer Science Review, Vol. 6 (2012), 187-208.
A. M. Shur, Numerical values of the growth rates of power-free languages, arXiv:1009.4415 [cs.FL], 2010.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Cubefree Word.
formula: Let L = lim a(n)^(1/n); then L exists since a(n) is submultiplicative. 2.7015614 < L < 2.7015616 (Shur 2012); the gap between the bounds can be made less than any given constant. - _Arseny Shur_, Apr 27 2015
example: There are 81 ternary words of length 4. Five of them contain the cube 000: 0000, 0001, 0002, 1000, 2000; same for 111 and 222. So, a(4)=81-3*5=66. - _Arseny Shur_, Apr 27 2015
author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
